comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: Dressed like a baseball player, no Google news hits for 1910–15. Could be Hubert W. "Mike" Flanagan, the minor league pitcher who played for the St. Joseph Drummers in the Western League in 1915: www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=flanag001hub

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Probably so, as there is a story in the 3/24/15 New York Herald that Flanagan had been working out with the Giants in Texas at their spring training camp, but had been returned to Muscatine, his minor league team.  In 1915, it was the Muscatine Muskies.  In 1914, they were called, of all things, the Muscatine Buttonmakers.

comment.author: 61849735@N00
comment._content: Muscatine IA is on the Mississippi river and fresh water clams were harvested and the shells were made into buttons.  Hence the name.  Not an unusual manufacturing point on river towns before plastic buttons.

comment.author: 40619665@N00
comment._content:
nice big buttons on that cardigan too!
=)
